A very popular neighborhood restaurant even though there's no signage.  There's a menu posted with the restaurant name.  And a huge sign that says Diamond Denistry above the entrance.  We were party of five.  Dinner at 6pm.  We were seated immediately.  Wine list, standard dinner menu, and daily specials.

I'm not big on sharing but we shared the snap pea with cantaloupe, and the arugula with chopped corn salads.  I liked both.

My entree - the potato gnocchi.  It was somewhat disappointing.  Too starchy and not pillowy.

We didn't have wine or dessert.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Positives: good location, warm ambiance, great food and good selection of wines
Opportunities: staff could be more attentive.
author: Greg S.

description: My 2 daughters and I had dinner here and overall we found it average. I had pasta which was supposedly house made. The sausage in the sauce was salty, portion was small. One daughter had ravioli which she liked. Other daughter had salmon carpaccio and the rolled eggplant appetizer. She liked both but portions were small. Bread was good. Atmosphere is warm and attractive. Would not come back here again. Better Italian food at home and I'm not Italian.
author: Linnie B.

description:
Cozy and clean.  Came here on a weeknight with my boyfriend near closing and left feeling very appreciative of the top-notch service despite it being so late.  Seafood was excellent- very fresh and with just enough seasoning to enhance the zest of our food without overwhelming its natural flavor.  

Will definitely visit again.
author: Lia S.

description: Great experience I really liked the attention to detail. Food was tasty and unique, and the service was excellent
author: Michael X.

description: I went for dinner there tonight with four other adults and 2 small kids.  Our servers were extremely friendly and accommodating of the kids. The food was definitely outstanding--fresh pastas and great sauces.  The salads were also fresh and delicious; I especially enjoyed the special radicchio salad.  Will definitely come here again!
author: Geraldine S.

description:
Don't pay attention to the arm chair wanna be critics. This place is outstanding!

I just ate dinner here and this place is great. The arugula corn salad is outstanding and the rissotto is delicious.

I recommend it for anyone who likes wonderful food prepared with care.
author: Kirk H.

description: Nice Glen Park neighborhood restaurant. Nice welcome, 5 star service with our waiter Mauricio doing an outstanding job. Food is well prepared with delicate flavors. We shared the burrata and prosciutto appetizer, arugula and roasted corn salad, pasta vongole and a chicken and veal entree. All the dishes were very excellent. The only criticism of the restaurant is the noise level. I love neighborhood restaurants and will return. Probably hit the spot early in the evening hoping to miss all the noise.
author: Dan S.

description:
I have visited countless Italian restaurants and believed that I could never leave unsatisfied... Until I came here. This is, hands down, the worst Italian restaurant I've ever been to, and the entire family agreed. I have no clue how this place scored a four star average with lackluster food and a dishonest waitress.

I made an 8:30 reservation through open table and came twenty minutes early to check in. Since it's a bit cramped inside, I went in alone and my family waited outside. There's no specified hostess so I waited for five minutes and the entire staff of 4 literally walked right past me. I get that they're busy, but they could at least acknowledge me and say, "Hey, I'll be with you in a moment." But no. So I dragged my family in, hoping they'll notice a larger party. After a minute or so, the waitress finally came around to confirm our reservation and told us it'll be around fifteen minutes. Okay, so we went out and walked around the local grocery store for twenty and came back at 8:40. When we arrived, a couple was waiting there. I saw the staff place a table in the corner, assuming that it was for us. And of course, the couple that walked in after us got to sit down first. So we asked why they got the table and the waitress said that it was a table for two. We were pretty far away at that time, so we didn't see the extra table that they could have parked together for our party of four. After we finally sat down after an additional ten or fifteen minutes, I spotted the table. Strike two. 

Mussels and Clams Appetizer

For $14, there wasn't enough on the plate. The mussel that I ate was fishy. But overall, the dish was okay with a flavorful tomato sauce that also worked as a dip. When we ran out of bread, we joked about getting it ourselves, since it was next to our table. We asked for a refill, and the waitress brought the remaining roll, stating that it was all they had left. But halfway into our meal, I watched as a different waitress opened a box from the cabinet and pulled out a roll of bread. Wow.

Pappardelle con Brasato di Maiale

(After we placed our order, she came back to tell us that they're out of the fresh pastas AKA the pappardelle and fettuccine, 2/3 pastas that we ordered, so we had to replace all of the dishes with rigatoni.)
This was below average. It only had a small hint of flavor and the ragu was disappointing compared to the previous times I've had it at other Italian restaurants. My sister said it tasted cheap. Too bad it wasn't at $19.

Rigatoni alla Bischero

This was the best among the pasta dishes. The tomato cream sauce was good and the family kept reaching for it. But the sauce overpowered the sausage so I couldn't taste it at all.

Fettuccine alle Vongole

There's an option of getting this with a white wine or the tomato cream sauce. My mom opted for the wine sauce and that was a mistake. It had no taste whatsoever. We flagged down the waitress, explained that it was bland and asked her to bring out a side of the tomato sauce. But she decided to counter us and say that that's how a white wine sauce is. Um, we know what we ordered and how it's supposed to taste. No apology for the food or attitude.

Bistecca di Manzo al Tartufo

At least the steak was redeeming. Cooked at a medium like we requested, and the char was great. 

One other thing that was commendable was the interior. It wasn't too crowded like most SF restaurants, and it was very warm (unless you're sitting right by the door).

This restaurant is now forever engraved in the Hall of Lame.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
Went here for dinner recently and it was great.  I had a basic salad and then ravioli.  The salad was delish -- it was a special of the day -- I can't remember everything they put in it and given - it's just a salad - but it was good.  The ravioli was great.  I didn't feel stuffed when I left and the food overall was great - so I was happy!

The server recommended a glass of wine to go with my choices and it was great too.  

Overall, I would go there again and have already recommended to a few friends -- hidden little gem.
author: Tracy S.

description:
I feel bad giving a bad review but I just cannot understand the rave reviews.  I assume it is a family run operation and everyone was very nice but the food was so disappointing.

The moment we got the bread I was worried,  it was cold and kind of hard, not in a good crusty way.  I was going to order the fennel salad but heard a lady next to us tell her companion not to get the fennel salad because it tends to be slimy.  So I ordered a crostini with fava bean spread instead.  It was ok but the salad that came with it was over dressed and limp and slimy.  My husband had the mussels & clams that he said were ok but the bread that came with it was burnt around the edges.

Our entrees were disappointing as well.  My husband ordered gnocchi and it looked awful and was completely drenched in a thick and oily cream sauce, it looked like clam chowder.  What a shame it was because the gnocchi had a good texture.  I ordered a sole special that came with polenta and spinach.  It was ok but the spinach was plain.

We skipped dessert and just wanted to get out of there. We both left very unsatisfied.  I give the 2 stars for the texture of the gnocchi and the service.
author: A. P.

description:
Hidden gem in Glen Park.

Consistently a good meal and service at Manzoni's. Went again last night and had the Insalata Riviera and Pappardelle con Brasato di Maiale with a glass of Mazzoni Toscana Rosso 2010. OK, maybe two glasses....

I can't praise this lovely restaurant enough and go as often as I can.
author: Katy C.

description: Came here for a bachelorette dinner of 10 people and services was SLOW! Did not get asked what we wanted to drink until 10 or so minutes after we sat down. They do not accept AMEX and they were just slow on all things. GREAT ITALIAN food but seemed more like a local regular place, not a tourist place or a good place for more than 4 people.
author: Jamie J.

description:
Two weeks ago on a Monday, my girlfriend, Donna, and our friend Sonny had dinner at Manzoni in the Glen Park neighborhood. For a little neighborhood restaurant, Manzoni was excellent! Far above what was expected! 

Donna and I had the Gnocci for our entrée! We both could not stop talking about it afterwards, and I think I even craved more later that night after we got home.

My appetizer was the mussels which were delicious. They were surprisingly easy to take out of the shell, and tasted wonderful.

Donna had the eggplant with cheese, and Sonny had a butternut squash soup. All of us each enjoyed our selected appetizer.

For dessert, I had the marvelous tiramisu. Donna had a chocolate hazelnut cake which she rather loved. Sonny had a cookies and ice cream dish he said was very good.

We shared a bottle of Merlot, and as with another review, the wine maker escapes me. It was a fantastic compliment to the meal. It says a lot about a Merlot when Donna likes it, since she isn't a fan of Merlots.

Annie, our server was delightful. She was cheerful, prompt and courteous...actually downright friendly, which made the evening fun for us all.

Manzoni is a quiet restaurant and even has two window tables. While Donna and I came with our friend, I firmly believe Manzoni would be a great place to go for a date night. I give Manzoni five stars!
author: Alan W.

description:
the food was just ok, especially for the price. 
it looks like a restaurant for locals. 
not worth a 20 minute drive to south.
author: hun y.

description: We made a reservation for a group of 10. After being seated and given water, we did not have a member of the waitstaff visit the table for 30 minutes. After finally ordering food and drinks we waited an hour for our food. 18% gratuity was included because of the size of our group, but we did not receive service that warranted that tip. The food was fine. I would only recommend for a date night as the restaurant is extremely small. If they don't want to care for a large group, they shouldn't accept reservations for groups.
author: Abigail B.

description: This is our first time here...celebrating Mother's Day..the good is absolutely amazing ...(2) specials today...Grilled swordfish, Penne Pasta and Atlantic Salmon, homemade ravioli with eggplant, zucchini and goat cheese in a light tomato sauce...everything is scrumptious...Congrats Manjel
author: Kim B.

description:
Best italian restaurant we've seen on our roadtrip! The restaurant is really cosy and tiny. But it looks like a real italian restaurant! Its very romantic there:)  we loved it. The service is amazing!! I ve never seen that before! They are all so lovely. 

The food was amazing. Everything was well cooked. The salads they have are very fresh and pretty fancy! So good! Then we had pasta and the gnocchis..! So delicious. The pasta was al dente!;)

I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Patrizia B.

description:
This is a cute little restaurant near BART.  We ordered the following and they were all great:
- wild arugula salad, pretty fresh
- polenta, it is a little different than the typical polenta but it's good
- fettuccine with clams and white wine sauce, flavorful but not too salty; though one of the clams had sands in it
-pappardelle, tender pork
-risotto, the pear made this dish interesting 
-tiramisu, so moist and yummy, a must order
-panna cotta, delish and not too sweet.
-chocolate hazelnut cake, very rich but a little too sweet for me
author: Veevee Y.

description:
We had a great dinner at this cozy place in GP recently.  The owner was very welcoming and offered us our choice of tables. The restaurant has a brick and stone interior which gives it a great feel.  

We had brought our own wine, so started off with that and some of their delicious foccacia bread served with a nice olive oil on the side.  I had the mussels to start, while the others had salads.  Two friends had the house salad, which left something to be desired as it was quite small and didn't have much going on.  My hon of hons husband had some sort of special salad with plenty of cheese and other delicacies and it was very tasty and plenty large. 

For my main course I had the salmon, which was delicious.  Served over amazing polenta (why doesn't mine every come out like that?) and the others in our party had risotto and ravioli.  Again, pretty delicious, but the risotto was lacking salt.

All in all a great addition to Glen Park - a real neighborhood gem.  Friendly and efficient service, good food and well priced.  

Check it out if you're in the 'hood.
author: .Hon H.

description:
What a great, cozy little Italian place!

My boyfriend and I went here last night for a Friday date. We made last minute plans, so I was struggling to find a place that would take us, but I called Manzoni's around 5'30 and they were able to accommodate the 2 of us for an 8pm reservation. 

I had the red wine special per our server's recommendation and my date had the white. The red was definitely better than the white, but if you like a really buttery finish, you might like the white wine. I don't know how often they change their glass wine specials.

We ordered the procuitto burrata for an appetizer and it took 30 minutes for the food to come out. My boyfriend was definitely getting a little peeved that the food was taking so long. When it finally came out, our server was very apologetic for the wait, and I believe the food was worth it. The burrata was delicious!

I tried to order the Pappardelle with pork ragu for my dinner. He had the shrimp. Unfortunately, they ran out of the pappardelle (they had run out of several items last night). The server was again, very apologetic, and made some other suggestions. I was having trouble deciding between the gnocchi and the ravioli. I finally decided on the ravioli, but to my surprise, my server returned and told me she had begged the kitchen staff to do a half/half plate of BOTH the ravioli and the gnocchi so I wouldn't have to decide! 

My boyfriend's shrimp was cooked well and it was flavorful. The ravioli was the best entree of the night. I highly recommend it. The gnocchi was soft and creamy and delicious as well, but I think the ravioli was better. We also had the tiramisu for dessert, which was good.

Overall, this is a small homey italian restaurant that serves unpretentious solid food. I love the atmosphere, food was yummy, and the service was great-- our server was super nice and attentive and made great menu suggestions. I definitely want to go back for the pappardelle that I missed out on!
author: Sy K.

description: Had a good experience here previously. Tonight the food was at best bland (2 stars), atmosphere was pleasant. Won't rush back.
author: Danielle M.

description: Solid, go to neighborhood italian - very attentive and personal service, charming space, food was fresh and tasty.  Combo with Saturday night jazz down the street at Bird and Beckett for a great SF night out that won't break the bank.
author: Matthew B.

description:
DELICIOUS! I want to go back right now!

My boyfriend and I tried this place last weekend and it was amazing.  We went on a Friday evening around 5:30 pm and got right in.

Their starter bread is amazing.  I had a glass of wine, delish.

He had the rigatoni with italian sausage and tomato cream sauce which was amazing and I had the special, fettucini with procuitto and mushroom in a cream sauce. So much flavor and excellent wait staff.

Will come here again soon!
author: Andrea Y.

description:
3.5 Stars

A quiet, cozy, and intimate place to spend the evening. The staff was very attentive without being intrusive. Our watier did not push us to order and was knowledgable when asked about recommendations for wine and food.

We had a girlled corn soup that was flavored wonderfully with bell peppers without the taste being overwhelming, especially since I am not a big fan of bell peppers. We were given plenty of time to finish before our entrees arrived. We got the pasta special that night and it tasted nice, though it was a little heavy on the salt. And also the risotto. I was not a big fan of it, but my dining partner was. 

I ended up choosing the tiramisu for dessert and apparently the staff was notified that it was my birthday and they actually put a candle on the tiramisu and used a menu to cover it up as they were bringing it to my table, since I was sitting facingthe kitchen. When they got to our table, they started singing "Happy Birthday" in Italian. Thank you, Manzoni Staff! That made my night.
author: Jay L.

description: When I compare Manzoni to bastions of excellent Italian food where I've eaten (Rome, Florence, Venice, North End of Boston, Little Italy in Denver, Wooster Square in New Haven, etc.), it shines. Two dishes that seldom meet their potential are done to perfection here: gnocchi and ravioli. I regularly order Involtino di Melanzane, Riviera salad, and a vegetarian pasta; I've never been anything but delighted. Everything from the ambiance, the gracious owner, the considerate servers, and the superior quality of the food makes for a delightful evening. I'm lucky enough to live within walking distance! Thank you Manhal and Marina for creating such a gem in Glen Park Village!
author: Kathryn K.

description:
What a treat!!! I was told to have low expectations with slower than usual service....when you are in Italy - who eats fast??? This place brings true italian food, culture, and passion for dinning. The service on this evening was perfect! The delightful owner also walks around and checks in....who doesn't love that???

The environment was hand made by the owner. Beautiful stone/tile and woodwork. He explained to us he learned his craft in Milano. The space is very personal and so are the staff. 

The food from appetizer to secondi was most excellent and the wine selection was perfect - delighted to be so transformed. Our only dissappointment for the evening was she dessert course. We were told to order the tiramisu (but they had run out) so we ordered the pana cotta which was a bit rubbery. 


also note: Seems to be an early crowd - we got there at 7:30 and the place was packed. By 9pm the space was mostly cleared. So go late if you want to enjoy a cozy evening with little crowd. *** just be sure to put in an early order for the Tiramisu!
author: Ron W.

description:
With no sign on the door, it's good there are plenty of windows for passersby to observe this perpetually bustling den of rustic Italian charm.  Walk in, take a whiff, listen to the heavy accents of the wait staff, and you know you're well on your way to a taste of la dolce vita.  

Our decadence began with proscuitto and burrata, a happy marriage of two of the most divine creations of an Italian kitchen.   We enjoyed ours alongside the fresh, warm bread and olive oil and a few sips of satisfying and modestly priced red wine. 

Homemade pasta is a must when you are at a trattoria that pulls and cuts its own, and we opted for the braised pork paparadelle and the daily special, a tortelloni stuffed with ricotta, chard and pine nuts and topped with a walnut cream sauce.

The paparadelle was a hearty, soothing antidote to a crisp evening - large chunks of stewed pork tossed with the tender, lightly chewy noodles.  The tortelloni was a perfect complement to the pork, featuring a creamy and subtly-flavored sauce accented with nutmeg.

We left fully content and deeply appreciative of this friendly, convivial and delicious neighborhood restaurant, a resurgent breed in our great city.
author: Derek W.

description:
Bottom line first, not worth the drive to the edge of the world. (For some reason, getting here from the Marina feels like crossing the world.

After a painful start, I will balance it out a little with some points for the service, while I felt I got too many "I don't know, everything is good" answers when consulting with the waiter, they were all very friendly and tried to be helpful.

The ambiance here is divided to two:

The good: The employees are Italian (or at least the ones I talked to) which gave a good feel to the dinner.

The bad: I just didn't like the restaurant table setup.. Maybe it's because we were a group of 7 and sat in a central table which was a different direction then the rest, but it just didn't click.

Unfortunately, the main reason for the 3/5 is the fact that for the price, the food was simply not to on par. The pappardelle was too hard to my taste and I didn't find anything else I tried from other people to be too exciting.

At time of review the place had 4.5 stars which I think is very over the top when compared to the many good places in the north beach area which are all 4 stars.
author: Assaf B.

description:
A great new addition to the restaurant scene in Glen Park.

We came here first with friends and then were back again a few weeks later with parents.  Both times the food was delicious, the atmosphere was pleasantly intimate but not-too-noisy, and bill was surprisingly reasonable.

The prosciutto and mozarella-like burrata appetizer was particularly special and along with some delicious Italian wine, it left us wanting to come back more.  The building is a lovely stone and brick space as well, nicely laid out.  We also saw the owner both times there watching over things and helping to ensure a quality experience (and actually served us on one occasion).

A new favourite in the Noe / Glen Park area.  We usually find parking pretty easily heading west on Chenery (away from the main intersection).
author: Robert S.

description:
I was quite impressed! The staff were very nice without being intrusive, the appetizers were great (the eggplant thing was to die for - and I don't even LIKE eggplant), the food generous and perfectly cooked. The wine nicely matched and the desserts more than I expected. All for a decent price. And none of this fancy art-work covering a tiny morsel of food on a giant plate; instead the plate was fully covered with good food. I felt like I had a Real Meal.

I have one minor complaint that I hope the owner addresses: the sauce for the steak wasn't quite right. Or, rather, it was as if they were made in separate parts of the kitchen and joined only as the plate went out to be served. The sauce was fine - but it just felt disconnected from the (perfectly cooked) steak. I would have liked a little simmer time in a sauce, or juices from the steak mixed in - something to 'marry' them together a little more. 

This is a minor complaint and I'm definitely going back to try the rest of the menu. I was thinking this would be a great place to bring my parents. Or a date. I'd even recommend the steak.
author: Luke A.

description:
This restaurant had been a long time coming since the nearby Bird & Beckett moved out. The owner (who also owns the nearby Higher Grounds coffeehouse) has made the place something of his labor of love, and it shows in the ornate brickwork he installed -- having shipped it in from overseas and carried by special trucks up from Long Beach.

They have a good, relatively inexpensive, and rather brand-name-heavy wine list. The service is spotty (though it opened only a week ago), and the food can vary from quite good to forgettable. For example, the gnocchi alla Piemontese is excellent: soft and pillowy with a cream sauce that doesn't overdo it and black truffle added to the mix. But then the Parma prosciutto with burrata is merely decent. The burrata lacked that freshly made irregularity -- it was a consistent texture, lacking the outer vs. inner layers that makes it a true burrata -- and the prosciutto was sliced a bit thick. And then the panna cotta was outright rubbery. So yeah...uneven.

Which makes us baffled by all the Yelptards who gave this place five stars. Seriously?! Must we act like yokels who have never been inside an Italian restaurant this side of a Sbarro or Pizza Hut? Talk about hyperbole. Not every good performance deserves a standing ovation, and not every good meal rivals the French Laundry in terms of quality.

It's a respectable three stars -- no more, no fewer. Just over the hill there's an Italian place that blows this out of the water at a "mere" four stars. Let's keep things in perspective, folks.
author: Teddy B.

description:
It was easy to think you stepped into a tratoria in Tuscany not only because the interior is authentically Tuscan, but the food tastes like it came straight out of an Italian kitchen.  

My wife and I had an arugula and corn salad to start that was made with incredibly fresh greens and sweet roasted corn.  She had the Bolognese which was very tasty.  I had a steak which practically melted in my mouth.  They have a wide variety of Italian wines to choose from.  We had a stupendous agnlianico.  The prices on both the food and wine were very reasonable.

It sounds like there may have been some rough spots in the service when the restaurant first opened, but my wife and I only experienced authentially warm and attentive service when we were there.

When we got there, the place was packed, but by the time we were finished, there was only one other table there.  The owner sat near us with a glass of wine and chatted with the two guys at the other table and us.  

We were  made to feel more like guests at a friend's house, than customers at a restaurant.
author: Jason S.

description:
The neighborhood has been waiting for this restaurant for over 4 years so it was such a nice surprise to see the place finally open.  

The room is beautiful.  Definitely one of the best looking restaurants in SF.  Lots of stonework, woodwork, & arches.  Lovely sconces on the wall as well as good artwork.  Maybe a tapestry can be put on the one long wall to buffer the loudness. 

I had dinner there Saturday night around 6:00pm.  The place was just about full.By the time I left @ 7:30pm it was packed & people were waiting. The menu has a wonderful selection in every category.  I ordered the fettucine (freshmade) with clams in a white wine broth -Excellent! It was just what I wanted, & how I like it made.  For dessert I had the chocolate hazelnut budino - Also excellent.

The service on the other hand was very spotty.  Nobody seemed to know what they were so supposed to do.  I was not sure who my actual server was as 3 people waited on me; & it seemed to be that way with everyone around me.  When I asked for my check, a 4th person brought it to me. 

The 2 people sitting next to me & I compared notes.  One ordered the pork chop - Very small, but cooked right, very moist, served w/carrots & broccoli.  The other person ordered the chicken - It looked devine also w/vegetable.  It looked better than it tasted - Very dry, she could not eat it.  All of us agreed the appetizer, salad & desserts (budino, & sorbet) were excellent.

Unfortunately, sitting next to us were 4 very loud women who made snide remarks on everything.  One even yelled at the waitress for accidently pouring wine in her wineglass because the patron had filled it w/water. How was the waitress to know that was not white wine in the glass?! So rude!  People  told them to cool it. 

I will go again to Manzoni. Right now I cannot really recommend it.  Having just opened maybe 2 weeks ago, the owners & staff still need to get alot of the kinks out both in service & food.  Once that is done, it surely will become a Glen Park gem!
author: Pam R.

description:
Dinner tonight was superb.  Great wine choice (made by the waiter).  Excellent 1st, 2nd, and desert.  I'm not big on hyperbole nor do I pretend to be a critic.  But I've spent considerable time and money enjoying great food and seriously great restaurants here and around the world and I was completely satisfied with the suggestions, the service, the presentations, and the food.

I admit that at my age, the menu was just a bit hard to read.  The color of the light blended in with the color of the menu which made me really have to work at sorting the details.  But once I just let go and ordered, I was in excellent hands!   

Manozoni is definitely worth checking out.  You will not be disappointed.
author: Paul R.

description:
Tried this place for the first time recently with a handful of relatives and it was wonderful. For appetizers we had the Parma Prosciutto y Burrata and a special that involved calamari, cannellini beans and tomatoes, and both were excellent. My nephew had the Bistecca di Manzo al Tartufo and spoke its praises rapturously. I had a ravioli special, stuffed with spinach and ricotta and finished with a lovely, mild tomato sauce with brown butter, that was one of the best pasta dishes I've ever had. A couple members of our party had a fresh mahi mahi special, and also sung its praises, as did those who had another pasta dish, the details of which I'm now forgetting. We skipped dessert as we had a fresh pie at home, so nothing to report on that, alas.

Service was friendly and attentive but not overbearing. In general the atmosphere was relaxed, cozy and friendly. I'm definitely going back. This is a neighborhood gem in a corner of town with several gems.
author: Bruce M.

description:
For some reason, I wasn't expecting a lot from this place and, as a result, I was pleasantly surprised.  We shared a great burrata/prosciutto/arugula appetizer followed by vegetable ravioli and some other delicious tomato sauced pasta.  My ravioli were definitely the highlight.  Portions not huge, but really tasty.  

Pasta dishes are $16-$19.  Appetizers circa $10.  

As some others have mentioned, the service needs some work but that will come in time.  

Great addition to Glen Park.  If you walk in with the right expectations, you will enjoy a nice meal.  This place is no Bacco, but it is way better than Lupo or Pasta Pomodoro.
author: Toby R.

description:
LOUD.  VERY LOUD.  WAY TOO LOUD.
My wife keeps telling me to turn down the volume
on Mahler or Marley, so I'm not averse to a few decibels,
but our experience at Manzoni at 8pm Saturday was just unacceptable.
Tile floors, wood ceilings, unadorned flat walls, brick arch;
nice clean look, but no sound absorbing surface anywhere.
We had to lean in over our table to hear anyone else in our party of 5,
and I saw people at other tables cupping their hands over their ears
in a vain effort to hear their dinner companions.  Our table
consisted of adjoined three small tables for two, each with
a triangular base, so on one side of each table leaning in
to hear caused the table to tip towards you.  Not good.

And I'm really sorry about the noise, because the food ranged from
good to superb.  I've cooked a lot of gnocchi, and ordered a lot of
gnocchi in decent restaurants, and Manzoni's was fabulous,
feather-light and delicately sauced.  Other pastas were equally
splendid, though tuna entree was not.  Desserts were exceptional too.

Service was mediocre, considering the price ($60/person with tip,
including wine but eating modestly.  The waitstaff was not
particularly attentive, did not know details of the menu without
asking the kitchen, and cleared plates while others were still eating.

In short: loved the food, but I won't go back because of the noise,
which basically ruined our dinner.  We were all very happy when we stepped
out the door into the quiet street.
author: Joseph S.

description: Food was great! Service was friendly and comforting.  I had an appetizer, and the pappardelle for my entrée, and both were wonderful.  The wine selection is concise but well-chosen.  I plan to return to try their gnocchi!
author: Soo S.

description:
Great Italian spot in the area!
Exterior of the restaurant is fabulous - that rustic Tuscan feel.
The decor/interior gives you the sense you are back in Italia, the workmanship with brick and stones really warms the place up. *Sigh* I miss Italy, Ok, moving on.
Service was great - not too slow, not too fast - let us take our time to enjoy each course we ordered/shared. Helpful with wine selection and selection food "this? or that?"

Food, was tasty, my husband and I split the following:
Insalata Riveria - corn was sweet and overall a great starter
Mussles and Clams - was the one more dissappointing dish - while the meats of the mussles and clams were fresh and plump, the sauce was lacking, we didn't want to slurp the sauce off the shells or use our bread to sop it up :( it needed something - white wine? parsley? something....they can easily fix it, the base it there.
Pasta: Pappardella with Pork ragu: was tender good size pieces of pork in a nice "gravy" as we say in my famiglia. Nice serving split for two!

We each had our main dishes:
I had the Pork medallions with capers/butter - was very good and pork was super tender!! I actually just ate the leftovers today for lunch and it was still tender!
My husband and the Veal scallopini - he enjoyed as well - recall there being a gratifying noise as he had his first bite!
Dessert - we were too stuffed, but when in Rome! So we ordered the Tiramisu to split of course - it was one of the best I have had in a LONG time. I am not a huge fan normally as it always dissappoints, but this was plate scraping! We somehow made room and inhaled the whole thing - what Tiramisu?
Prices are very reasonable and I hope they stay there for many years to come!! We each had (2) glasses of vino along with our meal for $150 incl tax and tip!
author: SF N.

description: A nice, small family-run Italian restaurant. Atmosphere is open/airy; hospitality is great. Menu is limited, but all dishes are good. We had 10 people and everyone enjoyed their selections. We didn't stay for dessert. Portions were small.
author: Stephen S.

description: Love this place because you can (almost) always get a table, the decor/ambiance is nice, and the customer service is great. The food is good too and not crazy expensive - my favorites are the arugula salad and the rigatoni with sausage and peas. Just taking off one star because we did the special Valentines Day pre fixe menu and the desserts - the most important part! - were disappointing (dry biscotti is all I remember).
author: Yangchen C.

description: It is soooo good. The ambience is pretty much family friend. The foods are amazing. We thought salad is pretty simple and we did not get the wow feeling until we have our entree and desserts. Also, the staff are very friendly. The price is on a pricy side, around $35-40 (including tips, without alcohol) per person. However, it is definitely worth it! such a little gem in Glen Park!
author: Yc C.

description: AMAZING SUMS IT UP!!! The atmosphere is great food is even better. Service is not an issue for me! It is just a little slow pace but c'mon people enjoy the beautiful interior have a glass of wine and relax! It's little Italy in glen park! YUMMY!
author: Sabrina M.

description: Came to San Francisco for a tattoo convention. Wanted to eat somewhere nice our last day in town. Mancini was excellent! The service and food are top of the line. 3 heavily tattooed guys got treated very well with no weird looks. Loved it all great experience!
author: Nando M.

description: Three excellent meals have earned a five star rating from us. Delicious food, intimate neighborhood environment, hospitable service. My Italian grandma would be impressed, I'm sure. Thinking of the veal again makes my mouth water. I've now eaten there with both friends and business colleagues. Great spot for both personal and business dining.
author: Paul M.

description: Excellent and very quaint. Came here based on the recommendations of the hotel staff where I was staying. I made a reservation through yelp commenting how it was my boyfriends birthday, please help me make it nice, and also please don't sing happy birthday to him because he hates that. Sure enough we showed up 20 mins early they still sat us right away, food was really good (to the point of remembering to write about it 6 months later) and they delivered a tiramisu with a simple "happy birthday" and walked away. I've already recommended this place to everyone I know going up there so go ahead and try it.
author: Jenni K.

description: Manzoni is an exceptional neighborhood restaurant, for so many reasons listed on this site, but I will highlight 4 things it has that keeps me returning to any restaurant. 1) The menu features excellent flavorful fresh produce in its pasta dishes and sides, locally sourced whenever possible, along with well sourced meats 2) The  bread, made on the premises, is out of this world in terms of taste and texture, and the olive oil a very high quality.. Ok technically that's already 4 things, I know, but it just have to add that the wines I drank were delicious, unusual, and affordable, and the owner is a gem of a guy committed to bringing Italy's best flavors to a night out in lovely Glen Park!
author: Sophie O.

description:
Italian food, much like Chinese or French or any other cuisine, will vary from country to country. An Italian restaurant in Germany will not taste the same as in the US. It is easy for restaurants to fall into the trap that they have to pile your plate with pasta, rush you through courses, remove a plate when your partner is still eating, the list goes on. Not so at Manzoni.

The joint is pristine inside and outside (we spotted the owner taking pride at his job by sweeping the sidewalk before opening). Again, a great sign of how things are done here.

A warm, genuine, unpretentious welcome starts the experience. We sat at the table closest to the bar and had a great view of the whole place, allowing us to enjoy the details, the cleanliness and the view of this small neighborhood's side street. With no signs outside, we had no idea this restaurant existed until we learnt about it through word of mouth.

The wine selection is very unusual: You will try a few and quickly realize that there is no bad wine at this restaurant.

The portions are just right and luckily closer to European standards. So is the service: No one will bother you with unnecessary questions that do nothing but rudely interrupt conversations. Instead, at all times attentive, staff will gently and politely do what they know how to do best.

It is an expensive night out and it was apparent that most parties were there to celebrate a life event. However, it money was not an impediment, we would certainly opt to dine here more often and already consider it a favorite if we fancy Italian food and a 'hidden' night out in town.
author: Nena G.

description: Very inviting atmosphere. Staff offered for my husband and I to sit inside while the kitchen opened because I was very cold waiting out front. The food was very good and they were accommodating to my dietary restrictions.
author: Heather G.

description: Wonderful, traditional Itlaian food.  Warm atmosphere and staff.  Will definitely be back again as this is the real deal.
author: p w.

description: This place is a real gem.  Everything we ordered was absolutely delicious, the decor / ambiance were really nice, and the service was also just wonderful.  The waiter (&owner?) really cared about your experience and wanted to ensure you enjoyed your dinner there.  All of the other tables seemed to have a great time too (overheard several people complimenting the owner.
author: S. M.

description: Last night we had the prosciutto and burrata appetizer and then the gnocchi and veal, all were delicious. The service was welcoming and excellentl. This is a nice authentic Italian Restaurant located in Glen Park. Definitely will be back.
author: Mark M.

description:
Tonight was my partner's and my 26th anniversary of being together.  I wanted a nice, predictable, no-nonsense-service trattoria experience like we've had in Italy and all I can say about Manzoni is SPOT ON.  Really, if I could figure out how to give 4.5 stars it would be only because I like a little citrus taste with my salmon and the salmon fennel carpaccio with which we started could've, accd'g to my taste, used some.  But that's just me because it really was delicious.  Our server was Italian and he knew his Italian wines.  I first chose a Friuli and he applauded my choice.  But with the gnocchi... which hands down, was the BEST gnocchi my partner and I have ever head (little pillows of tender flavor explosion, garnished with a peppering of black truffle in a cheese sauce that was light and partnering like an experienced dancing leading man)... he suggest another white which escapes me now (Gravi a Gravi or something like that).  Light, yet full of character and complexity.

Then the salad, which was mixed spring greens with julienned apples, with a berry vinaigrette that just floated on the greens... not heavy but a great partnership  ...Are you getting it yet?  We were having a GREAT time.  All you detractors, I'm sorry you had a bad time but I'm glad we didn't go on the nights you did.

Followed the main meal, which was vitello scallopine... veal scallopine toped with pancetta and a cheese which I forget. Again... a pillow of texture and flavor and our waiter suggested a wonderful Piemontese red which he had me taste first (hot... high level alcohol I thought, but delicious).  When I confirmed that I liked it and he brought a glass, he explained that this new glass may taste differently because it was a new bottle and hadn't breathed yet.  Detail.  Love it.

Tiramisu and chocolate budino for desert.  Both the best we've had... and another wonderful suggestion for a desert wine by our waiter.

Prices were just right... I mean we spent close to $200 with tip but we ordered like it was our 26th anniversary, and I know we would have paid $100 more for the same experience at some nouvelle Amero-Italio-nouvelle whatever place.  The service was attentive and non-intrusive, and detached in that charming European kind of way.

I'm sold.  We will be back.  Tante grazie, Manzoni... era veramente un piacere mangiare stasera.
author: Ric S.

description: Excellent food, tasty! Great value for the money! I highly recommend !!Fantastic food and great service! I highly recommend!
author: chris c.

description:
Love this place.  Eat there frequently, one of our favs.  Warm and inviting staff.
Must have the corn and arugula salad, raviolis are always a treat, great veal and to die for alfregado!   Next time heading back for the burrata appetizer - looked yummy!
author: Cincia H.

description:
Glen Park, a neighborhood, of San Francisco, CA, USA, has a BART station, and a ton of wonderful restaurants...  French, Italian, Mexican, American, Breakfast, Sandwiches???  They are all covered; but only Mike has two restaurants, in the neighborhood, Manzoni's  and Higher Ground, both of which are exceptional... (see separate review of Higher Ground) but Manzoni's is a true Glen Park jewel...  Better Italian food, in San Francisco, would be hard to find; which is saying a lot, in SF, CA, USA...  North Beach has long been the king of Italian SF neighborhoods, but Manzoni's is an exception to the rule...  Mike, the owner/operator is an Italian "old school" guy, who spent quite awhile, personally, creating a Tuscan atmosphere, in Glen Park/Diamond Heights...   Then, add a fabulous wine list and menu, and old-world charming service, and you have Manzoni's, a truly European epic Renaissance restaurant in SF, CA, USA... 
Over the years, we have had, or seen, virtually everything, on the ever-changing menu, and, "It's all goood..."  Thanks, Mike, for an epicurean delight...!!!
author: CDR JAY C. O.

description: Just went here last night and had a great dining experience. We had the risotto special and the pappardelle con brasato di maiale (pasta with braised pork). Both dishes were amazing, I especially liked the pappardelle con brasato di maiale. For wine, we had a bottle of Grigio Sartori Soave Anselmi San Vincenzo which was nice and light. Finally, for dessert we had the Affogato (vanilla gelato topped with whipped cream and a shot of hot espresso). Everything was excellent including the service. The staff was very friendly and attentive without being pushy. The setting was intimate and perfect for a date night or small groups. I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Casey P.

description: This restaurant opened up recently so i wanted to check it out. Several friends and i went one Friday night and was very impressed with the service and delicious food. The ambiance was pleasant despite how small the restaurant was, with a very Italian cultural feel. We ordered mussels for appetizers which we all enjoyed and we each loved our entrees. ( i ordered ravioli, a friend ordered chicken, and another friend ordered gnocchi).  The waiters were very attentive and always refilled our glasses of water. If you plan to come here on a weekend, i highly recommend making reservations because the place gets pretty busy.
author: Karla M.

description: Prosciutto e burrata plus the gnocchi were great.
author: Dan D.

description: The owner is a neighborhood legend, for years having served excellent crepes across the street from Manzoni for 364 days per year to a cult-like following. We've long-awaited the opening of Manzoni and it looks great. It's charming with brick and ivy and cozy in a lovely way (not as a euphimism). We haven't eaten inside yet but we took a bunch of entrees for takeout. So many options, pastas and meats and it's hard to choose!
author: Marina N.

description: Manzoni's is a wonderful restaurant with great service and great food. The staff there are very attentive, friendly and helpful. I took my daughter there to celebrate her birthday along with a group of her friends. The staff made my daughter and her friends feel very special, and brought out the birthday cake (that I had bought separately for the occasion) with lit candles and singing for her etc. The food was delicious, it was a marvelous evening, thanks to the staff at Manzoni's.
author: Sue B.

description: This was my second time here, the first time was nothing special.  So we tried it again and went to have dinner last week, the place was busy but not full.  The food turned out to be nothing special and the service was inefficient and confused (like the waitress and waiter had never done this before) - which I know they had.  I won't go back.
author: David H.

description: My mouth waters just thinking about this place. It's definitely a gem in this neighborhood. My only critique is that it's pricey & I had 3 courses and was still hungry. Maybe I'm just a fatty. Definitely worth it if you're feeling fancy.
author: Aaron H.

description: After talking to neighbors who had a good experience here, we decided to go back  after a disappointing first visit last August. We had a completely different experience. Great meal and friendly staff. Better acoustics would help.
author: Rick P.

description: This is a welcome addition to the neighborhood.   The food is good,  but I had the pappardelle with pork sugo, (lots of big juicy cubes of pork) sadly no comparison to the versions from Perbacco or Incanto, and my husbands pork medallions were on the dry side.  The fennel salad and artichoke soup were indeed yummy and the service is friendly.  Manzoni needs sound proofing in the tastefully decorated room as its difficult to hear the waiter recite the specials or have decent dinner conversation across a 2-top.  I'll go back because I want to see them succeed, Manzoni just needs a bit of fine tuning.
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description: This is such a charming place. The owner and staff are friendly and helpful. The food is always delicious. The house made pasta is wonderful. The house wines are yummy and a good bargain. It's our favorite place in Glenn Park.
author: WhatDoIKnow S.

description:
Glen Park is enjoying a dining establishment renaissance in this holiday season, with the opening of Tataki Canyon on Chenery and Manzoni on Diamond in the former space of Bird & Beckett. You would not recognize it today! The restaurant opened this week and is still a bit rough around the edges in terms of moving plates from kitchen to customer, but the staff are all pleasant and sincere. We were seated promptly in the early evening and our water glasses were attentively filled. Unfortunately, timing was a bit of an issue as we waited over 45 minutes for our pasta entrees after the appetizers came and, at one point, we were asked whether we wanted to see the dessert menu before our entrees had arrived. I think they forgot our order for awhile. Even so, I do not have the heart to give this place less than 4 stars, because it is opening week afterall and the dining choice is much-needed in the Village. If you've ever been to the owner's other establishment, Higher Grounds Coffee House, you know it is a humble operation but excellent, excellent food.

I had a sliced fennel salad that was fresh and crisp and a pork ragout pappardelle. The food is very straightforward and satisfying. The menu has a diverse selection of pastas as well as main entrees (New York steak, roasted half chicken and others) . We did not try dessert, but the ones that passed our table looked substantial. The prices are reasonable, with appetizers and salads in the $8-10 range, pastas about $16 and full main entrees around $22. The wine list fills two pages.

This week, the place is cash only as the credit card machines have not come in yet. We will surely be coming back in a few weeks once the kitchen and front of the house normalize.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
We went to this gorgeously appointed new Italian Restaurant on New Year's Eve and had a wonderful meal.  My partner and I both had a delicious shrimp dish with beautiful lemon garlic and mediterranean aromatic flavors.  It was served with gorgeous roasted squash and Brussels sprouts.  The whole thing was presented with glamour and was filling and delicious.  To start we had a beautiful roasted eggplant dish--goat cheese, avocado, smoked salmon, rolled inside--which was stunning, and a fennel salad, made with a light, flavored olive oil or some other fine oil, also excellent.   I rate this shrimp and eggplant as outstanding worthy of five stars and the fennel salad as excellent four stars.  We also had a great and reasonablly priced wine from Sicily.   The service is warm and professional.  The restaurant is beautiful, comfortable, warm with soft light and the wooden interior seems to absorb noise well so if you like to talk to your dinner mates, it's a find.  If you like the bistro food and the vibe at Petit Laurent, you will also love this place just diagonally Diamond Street.  We will definitely go again soon.  

By the way, in contrast to a prior reviewer who complained of grade inflation, i.e. giving five star ratings when The French Laundry is a gold standard for five stars restaurants, I note (having been several times) that the French Laundy costs about $250.00 per person on a cheap day.  Manzino offers wonderful food with  professional, warm service and a friendly atmosphere in our neighborhood for $30 to $50 per person without driving anywhere or making a reservation six months in advance!   There should be five stars for different classes of restaurants, not just the super luxe of the luxe.  Manzino is doing what it sets out to do on its terms wonderfully.  I have also had a lot of two to three star dishes at Incanto over the hill in Noe Valley.  This cuisine compares favorably in quality with La Ciccia, but very different in style.
author: Hillel M.

description:
A very fine addition not just to the neighborhood, but to the city. The care that has gone into the interior design and construction, the not-ordinary but still very authentic menu, the desserts, the wine list, the dedication of the owner and staff ... all portend great things for this restaurant. 

Last night my wife and I shared the polenta and a salad, the raviolis and  pork tenderloin, and shared a superb Piemontese budino for desert. We left happy and feeling like we had been to a very good authentic ristorante of the sort we are used to in our stays in Italy.

Highly recommended!!

September 1 2014

Last night with 9 friends - another lovely meal at Manzoni.

I had just a bite of the gnocchi - never tasted one so delicate. Well formed yet literally melts in your mouth. Next time, that's for me!

My own spaghetti putanesca was excellent. Not my favorite on the menu, but very well made.

The sorbetto di pera was incredible.
author: Paul R.

description: It was fine. But not good enough to go back. The service was pleasant and the food was ok. But not really special. Everything tasted flat basically. We aren't sorry we ate there, but with so many other choices in the city, I think they need to improve their flavor profile.
author: Kat B.

description:
We don't have enough restaurants like Manzoni here in San Francisco.

My wife and I started with the salmon tartare and mussels & clams in a spicy broth. Both were terrific. My veal and my wife's pasta vongole were presented perfectly and left us very satisfied. Nice portions, very fresh ingredients, and piping hot. 

Our server gets kudos for pacing our meal well, being attentive without being all over us, and providing her recommendations candidly and simply. We wanted for nothing throughout the meal and considering the epidemic of attitide and indifference affliciting servers throughout our City, Manzoni hit the sweet spot.

Our shared chocolate budino was scrumptious. The owner personally checked to see that all had been in order, something again, all too often lacking in 'fine' San Francisco contemporary dining. And the price was an eye opener - reasonable cost for a great, great dining experience.

Thanks Manzoni, you can be sure that we will be back.
author: Bill G.

description: Take a mini vaca to Tuscany in Glen Park! A GREAT neighborhood restaurant! The food is exactly what you would expect in Italy. Authentic dishes and genuine service. Plus, a fantasting wine list (I would recommend the Nero d'Avola) all between $20-$50!
author: Sonia S.

description:
Went three-ish weeks after opening.  3 of us all really enjoyed our meals.  The vibe and internals are all very beautiful.

The service hopefully gets worked out -- three waitstaff members seemed overwhelmed by the half-full restaurant.  Nice staff but confused and slow.

Happy its in the neighborhood; hopefully they figure out the service and a reservation system (we did a walk-in because we couldn't figure out how to book ahead of time).  I'll revisit this review if the service improves a bit...
author: John B.

description: What a delightful little piece of Italy, more elegant than a trattoria, but not pretentious. We liked the grilled corn salad. I  particularly loved the rissoto, which is a mark of a good kitchen. The pasta dishes are all great, in fact, we liked everything we tried. The owner is gracious and the servers do not cop attitudes like a lot of restaurants.  A nice wine list that pairs well with the food. I liked that the decor reminded me of being in Italy.
author: Steve G.

description:
I'm no "foodie" but I live in Glen Park, and I can tell you I'm happy to have another great little restaurant in the neighborhood! I've eaten there several times now, and have always thoroughly enjoyed my meal.  

I've always been there on a weeknight, so there's never been a wait for a table on the nights I've gone.  In addition to the excellent food, the interior is very attractive.  Check it out!
author: Jeffrey P.

description:
Great food, even better owner. A wonderful addition to Glen Park!

The ravioli was absolutely amazing, as was the pork. Ownership took time to talk with us about the meal, and give great suggestions. We are going back soon!
author: Brian G.

description: This was well worth the years of waiting for it to open.  There is a simple, rustic elegance; the ambiance is wonderful, but not surpassed by the food.   We will be back soon, and write in more detail about the food next time.  The tiramisu was a joy,  fresh, and you could taste all of its ingredients.  And we will be bringing friends and guests to this treasure.
author: Joel S.

description:
My toddler broke a glass on himself and the staff flew to our side, checked him for glass shards, helped me whisk him out of his chair and then cleaned it all up, all the while checking to make sure we all were ok.  We did not get a single eye roll.  They are very kid friendly and tolerant.

Their risotto is divine.
author: Simona A.

description: Manzoni is a wonderful addition to the Glen Park restaurant scene. The proprietor also owns Higher Grounds, a nice crepe place located kitty corner. Manzoni has beautiful brand new  decor-- stone and wood. You feel like you're in an intimate  restaurant in Florence. The wait staff is attentive and friendly, but you never feel rushed.  In fact, it has the relaxed pace of a restaurant in Italy. Appetizers we had were excellent: prosciutto w/ burrata was succulent and salmon tartare fresh and tasty.  The fettucine w/ clams is a star dish-- I had the white sauce.  Pork medallions were moist and flavorful in a creamy sauce. Risotto w/ mushrooms rocked. Rigatoni with sausage in a tomato cream sauce was also tasty.  Desserts: panna cotta was good, but chocolate hazelnut cake was out of this world! Note:  still cash only as of 1/14/12.
author: charles g.

description: The food is fabulous. We especially enjoyed our main dishes (I had the gnocchi and my husband had the puttanesca) and the amazing hazelnut budino (a cross between pudding and cake) we shared for dessert. The ambiance is warm and inviting -- the owners obviously put a lot of care and expense into creating a beautiful dining room -- if a bit too dense with tables. We were very impressed and we're delighted to have another excellent dining option in our neighborhood!
author: Jessica L.

description: The reviews to date tell me that either I was at this place at a very off night or that most reviewers do not know a good place to eat. This place is horrible. We arrived at 6:50 pm and finally got out of there at 10:00 pm. We waited 1 hour between the salad and the entrée. The food was marginal-over priced and the service was horrible. I will never go to this place again-ever.
author: Herman l.

description: I came here on a saturday night with 2 friends. The food was great! The portion size was a bit small for the price (avg dish is about $20 bucks) but overall pretty good. I ordered the tiramisu ($8) for desert and was pleasantly surprised. After reading all of the other reviews i was expecting to be blown away by the service. Our waiter was excellent BUT the owner was very rude to him, he kept barking orders at our waiter and seemed to be picking on him (i.e get them water, get them the check) before the poor guy could even do anything. IDK may have been having a bad day, but i hope this is not the norm.
author: V I P.

description:
My first visit was on 10/30/12 and brought friend for his birthday dinner. The ambiance and decor were so reminiscent of an old Roman osteria was remarkable. The food was very good for both of us. I had a grouper fish special and it was outstanding, perfectly cooked and seasoned and served with broccoli rabe - love it. My friend had a rigatoni dish that was light and tasty.

I highly recommend Manzoni. The owner was very kind and attentive. I'll be back.
author: Garrett S.

description:
Charming old world ambiance, excellent service, food is authentic in the northern Italian style.   I went  with two friends, we ordered two different starters ( great bean soup) and three main course plates. All were good, only one was a disappointment, Risotto, too salty.   Wine list very fine and may I say the prices are most reasonable. 
i'll be back.
author: Mary S.

description: Delizioso! The intertwining of flavors was wonderful to the palate. The "wine of the night" was flavorful and reasonably priced. The server suggested appetizers to complement the main courses, when we asked for suggestiond ... and his choices were spot-on. The service was friendly and attentive. I'm not usually a big fan of Italian desserts, but the panna cotta was thick and rich, with just the right amount of dark cherries to add a counterbalancing flavor note. We'll definitely be back to this neighborhood gem.
author: Rich W.

description: We've been waiting for over a year for this restaurant to open.  And it was worth the wait.  The owners have created a warm inviting space that transforms you to Europe. The staff is very friendly and efficient which adds immensely to Manzoni's charm as a wonderful neighborhhood restaurant.  The food is solid, though not exceptional. Most of the dishes  we had (lentil soup & risotto special, corn/arugula salad,  pork entree, and budino) were very good.  The fish special I had was good, but not so good that I would order it again.  Overall our first experience was wonderful and we will definitely go back.
author: Brad W.

description: We love Manzoni!!!  We went here recently for our anniversary dinner and it was lovely as usual!!!  Great wine list, all the pasta dishes have been delicious and the daily specials are wonderful.  I highly recommend this restaurant for a special night out.  It is truly a neighborhood gem!!!
author: Shannon V.

description: great food but I can't afford to go back because the Nero d'Avila, the cheapest wine in the house, was $9.50 a glass.  My bad-- the wife and I like to linger over a two glasses each and, including tax and tip, that means fifty bucks on the bill for vino.  The waitress told me the corkage fee was $18.50.  If they lowered their corkage fee, or offered a house wine for a reasonable price we'd be there once a week.  Great resto for techies just off the bus, but not for us
author: greg c.

description: The food is terrific, the wait staff is so sweet and friendly, and the decor is extraordinary. Will go again and again.
author: Oschla G.

description:
Food is outstanding - buonissimo.  Our group of 7 shared 3 primi and we each had a secondo (entree')..
Every plate was excellent.  The Pastas are fatto in casa (made by the chef) and are as good as I have tasted.
My cousins from Piedmonte will be very impressed when they arrive this Spring.
Grazie mille for a great dinner.  Dawn, Glen Park
author: Dawn I.

description: My family and I have now been there 3+ times.  Every dish we have tried has been amazing.  The Panna Cotte and Chocolate boudin are delicious, and the pasta is super fresh.  Everything is very fresh.  The service has really worked itself out and the experience at Manzoni is excellent.  Can't wait until next time! Grazie!
author: Gina I.

description: Tuscan decor, quaint setting,  i started off  open food beet salad  9.50 and guazzetto Mediterranean mussels toasted bread was a bit charred 8.50 friend had special  petrale fish 25.00 and mushroom soup 8.50 two wine special  20.00 and tiramisu very authentic delicious a bit pricy overall great and fresh food, owner Aldo owes the crepe place.... He knows his stuff would good back again ... RSVP recommended after 7:30 very busy and noisy....
author: Lisa M.

description: Another reason to come to glen park.  Good service great wine and food.  Fantastic desert menu
author: David H.

description: average italian food. great wine selection
author: Albert M.

description: Delicious! The risotto was a special that night, with shrimp, prosciutto and lemon! Bottle of Italian wine, the evening special was $10.50 - a bottle, not a glass! Salads and appetizers were wonderful too.
author: J L.

description:
Manzoni is a great addition to Glen Park.  I've eaten there at least 10 times. The interior is very nicely done. It's a bit tight on space and can be noisy but is worth the trip. Do not be in a hurry or prissy when you get there. The staff is very friendly, even if a bit unorganized at times if the place is packed . The food is amazing that's all I can say about it and the tiramisu  is to die for. 
The place is new and has a few bugs to work but overall it's got a great start as far as I'm concerned. Great place to go on a date or with good friends. Don't be in a hurry and relax and enjoy.
author: bill l.

description:
outstanding dinner Thurs 6/13
delicious fresh tomato soup
gorgeously seasoned sole with mustard greens and polenta
wonderful Italian beer
generous portions
everything teeming with freshness and just right cooking
this week, this quiet place outserved Central Kitchen and La Ciccia--other places I like
author: Eric H.

description: Simply put, we love this place. A warm and elegant atmosphere, always good service. I always appreciate their wonderful salads, great choices for pasta dishes, meat or fish. The food is fresh, never too salty or heavy. A big plus is you can actually carry on conversation without shouting. So glad to have this delightful place in the neighborhood.
author: Julie C.

description:
In reading a lot of these reviews before coming here, I wasn't sure the lesser reviews were snobby entitled folks or those with general and valid complaints. I decided to try the place and it seems there is a lot more snobbiness and entitlement than merit. It really makes me question the value of yelp. It seems that people either love or hate things enough to write about it. It reminds me of a study that I read about surveys in general that elaborated on motivation factors which include passionate experiences, bad experiences, or financially motivated ones. Bottom line, all reviews fall into one of these three categories. Yelp has created a new category. I like to call it the "I'm bored but think I'm clever and witty so i will write about places and judge them harshly" category. Yelp is full of reviews like this. They have no merit. For that reason, I pledge today to never again consider yelp reviews as fair or accurate, just entertaining at best.  So read my  review if you want...trust it if you want...but don't get let down if you disagree...

...and don't complain if the kitchen won't make your snot nosed little kid a special pizza

...and don't complain if the credit card machine goes down

...and if you don't like it, go to another restaurant and don't take it a personal vendetta against you such that you have to write a review like you're friggin' Anthony Bourdain or something. 

Basically get over yourself.  OK onto my review.

Food was great...nothing frozen...all prepared fresh and it was obvious!  Well served, well presented, great menu options for a true trattoria experience, which I believe was the concept here (tuscan if I'm not mistaken).  A really great example of what you would get in Italy...none of the California or American fusion that perverts a lot of Italian restaurants.  Keep it up Manzoni...I'll be back
author: jacob s.

description: I think the owner of Manzoni is the hardest working man I've ever seen, and it really shows in his food. You can get a delicious crepe from him the the morning across the street at Higher Grounds, and then be warmly greeted by him at night at this fancy Italian restaurant. The atmosphere is very warm and inviting. They play opera. I hate opera, but I liked it when I was there. All of the dishes we got were delicious, but the best was a salmon appetizer. They have plenty of fish and exciting vegetarian options for those of us who are carnivorously challenged. I'd give them one more star if they featured organic meats. At the end of the dinner we had the door opened for us and were told "Goodnight." I love these people and I hope they stay here for a long time!
author: Diana M.

description: Wow!  This unassuming little place really blew me away.  The service was excellent...very attentive.  The wine selection was the tops.  But, it was the food that was most impressive.  I ordered the ravioli and while it looked quite simple, the flavor was incredible.  I usually woof my food down, but I made a point at taking my time once I took my first bit.  Definitely try the tiramisu...authentic and homemade.  I had never heard of the place until friends asked if I wanted to try it.  Now I'm glad to spread the word.
author: Rich B.

description: We went back after a long absence and found the food got even better.  A super local restaurant serving fine Italian cuisine.  Warm decor, very European.  Friendly and competent staff.  Having been here several times I find the food reliably good to excellent.  Reasonable prices, good wine list, portions are just right, not small and not overly large.  Excellent place for couples or a group.
author: Tessie S.

description: Every time I go there I feel the same old feeling when I used to go to Italy, and the food is just great.
author: Raymon H.

description: I ate here with two family members for the first time tonight.  Delicious food made more scrumptious by the lovely ambience and truly gracious service.  Great inventive salads, wonderful ahi tuna, excellent wine.   When our ahi tuna dish was late in coming - even before we knew it was late - our server brought us a gratis (and yummy)  shrimp and pasta dish to fill the delay.   We didn't order dessert, mentioning we were tempted by the hazelnut chocolate cake but were just too full;  but because the server knew this was a birthday dinner we were surprised with a takeout box of hazelnut chocolate cake with "happy birthday" written on the box, accompanied by the owner and two servers quietly singing a happy birthday song in Italian  Real class!  A restaurant that deserves to succeed.  We'll definitely be back.
author: Fran D.

description: My husband and I came here Sunday night, fairly early, and it was delightful to be there.  I had the mussels & clam cioppino appetizer.  I would have loved this as a main course.  I also loved the salads.  The owner is a lovely man, talked to us for a while.  Main courses are about $22.00, appetizers about $10.00.  I loved the look of the place.  Very like a restaurant in Italy.  I would highly recommend this place.
author: Prabha M.

description: We really enjoyed Manzoni. We live in Glen Park, so had been waiting for it to open for some years. The place, which used to be the wonderful bookstore / jazz venue Bird & Beckett (now up the hill on Chenery and still the cultural and musical center of this part of the city) has been transformed, handworked wood and brick giving it a warmth complemented by the owner, who greeted us and took us through the menu. Much of the menu was surprisingly elegant and quite, quite good.
author: Lawrence C.

description: I am baffled that the place is listed as not good for kids. They were ridiculously obliging, invented a kids menu for my toddler, came equipped with squeaky clean high chairs, but amazingly managed to retain the nice-fancy-night-out dinner vibe. It's another great win for the neighborhood (which already had a fantastic French place) with nice decor, a ridiculously friendly owner that really goes out of his way to make sure you're having a good time, and very good food. We had a party of 6 and one just average meal, the rest were top notch. Pasta quality was great, and overall I am thrilled to not have to deal with the parking nightmare in North Beach to finally get good Italian.
author: Jess L.

description: Great Glen Park neighborhood restaurant. Fresh pasta and ingredients. Try the pork ragu or the fresh fish dish. Also love the prosciutto and burratta appetizer.
author: Cassie M.

description: For a few hours we were in Italy. THE best Italian food in San Francisco! Bravo!
author: Alex L.

description: Starting with the plus side: Manzoni's food is terrific, and the prices are in line with San Francisco. It's wonderful to have an Italian restaurant in Glen Park at long last. On the down-side, there's no organization to the wait-staff, they all seem to just run around without a clue as to what they are doing. No one is assigned to water or bussing tables or greeting at the door. That everything eventually gets done is kind of a miracle. The room is typical of San Francisco: way too loud - nothing was done to mitigate the sound (a little acoustic softening goes a long way - drapes, anyone?), and the chairs have wicker seats, which will certainly help them turn over tables quickly, but which don't add comfort to the list of attractions. By all means go - but you may want to pick a slow night (we went on a Saturday), in order to save yourself some grief and some hearing loss. Manzoni's is closed on Sundays and Mondays.
author: Jeremy C.
